review_title: Non profit IFA that invests in children, families and their staff to ensure the best outcomes for children.
job_title: Supervising Social Worker in Maidenhead, England
pros: - Non profit IFA. Every penny goes to improving the lives of the families we serve via direct support and the promotion of best practice in recruiting quality staff who are supported with regular supervision and training. - Strength based models for practice are imbedded such as signs of safety and the STAR models. - Managers are present members of the team, know their work force and the families that they serve. - There is a clear structure for training and advancement.
cons: - There is a national shortage of social workers which impacts all boroughs. We try to focus on staff retention strategies as well as attracting quality personal. - We are employed by an IFA with all the associated benefits of a private non profit company but also retain a Local Authority pension via RBWM. Thus The best of both worlds.

job_title: Deputy Head of Section in London, England
pros: I have worked as part of Richmond Council prior to the creation of Achieving for Children and have chosen to continue with this new organisation due to the joint mission we set out and how supportive and engaged the AfC community continues to be. From the top down staff feel valued and heard, and AfC is an organisation that is keen to develop and nurture staff, this has been my experience having started in a temporary role and worked my way up, during which time I have felt supported to realise my potential. Senior Leadership are consistently present and regularly check in with staff and teams to support well-being, including during the difficult Covid-19 pandemic, all alongside dedicated well-being support made available online to all. There is a real sense of community and coming together in AfC and for me, having worked within the organisation in different roles since it's conception, I highly recommend joining us!
cons: The only thing I would note here is the need for senior leaders to not only seek views from staff via conversation and surveys, but also to experience the current day to day demands in differing roles within the organisation. I believe this gives a different and new level of understanding of both what is going well on the ground, but also helps to identify those areas which need further development or investment.
